title: Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV)
author: Kara Mayer Robinson

sections.heading: What Is Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV)?
content: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is a common, contagious virus that affects your respiratory system. It spreads easily and leads to cold-like symptoms such as a runny nose and cough.

Most people with RSV have mild symptoms that go away on their own in a week or two. But RSV can lead to serious complications, especially for babies, older adults , and people with certain conditions.
If you have RSV and you can’t breathe well or you’re dehydrated, you may need to go to the hospital. You may need IV fluids, oxygen, or ventilation (which helps with your air flow).
When is RSV season?
In the U.S., RSV season begins in the fall, peaks in the winter, and starts to slow down at the end of spring. But it varies from year to year.

content_blocks.text: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is a common, contagious virus that affects your respiratory system. It spreads easily and leads to cold-like symptoms such as a runny nose and cough.

Most people with RSV have mild symptoms that go away on their own in a week or two. But RSV can lead to serious complications, especially for babies, older adults , and people with certain conditions.
If you have RSV and you can’t breathe well or you’re dehydrated, you may need to go to the hospital. You may need IV fluids, oxygen, or ventilation (which helps with your air flow).
When is RSV season?
In the U.S., RSV season begins in the fall, peaks in the winter, and starts to slow down at the end of spring. But it varies from year to year.

sections.heading: RSV Symptoms
content: RSV often looks like a common cold.
Common RSV symptoms include:

content_blocks.text: RSV often looks like a common cold.
Common RSV symptoms include:

content: With RSV, you may develop more serious symptoms. When RSV goes into your lower respiratory tract, it may lead to pneumonia or bronchiolitis . Bronchiolitis is when the small airways that lead to your lungs get inflamed.
Severe RSV symptoms include:
It's possible to have RSV without a fever as well. RSV can also cause a headache, an ear infection, eye discharge, or hives .
It’s not common to have RSV and diarrhea, vomiting, or loss of smell.
If you have mucus with RSV, colors to watch for include yellow, green, or gray. Call your doctor if you see these colors.
Emergency symptoms of RSV in children include:
RSV can quickly go from mild to serious, especially in kids.
Young babies have a high risk of severe RSV, so if your baby is less than 6 months old, seems sick, and has signs of RSV, call your doctor.
bullets: A cough that lasts more than 4 days
No desire to eat or drink
Thick mucus that’s yellow, green, or gray

content_blocks.text: RSV can quickly go from mild to serious, especially in kids.
Young babies have a high risk of severe RSV, so if your baby is less than 6 months old, seems sick, and has signs of RSV, call your doctor.

content: It’s also important to call your doctor if your child has a high risk of complications.
RSV cough
An RSV cough is usually dry. If it’s a serious case of RSV, the cough may sound more severe.
Children with RSV may develop croup, or a cough and a sore, scratchy throat. If you have severe RSV, you may develop bronchiolitis, which may make you cough more.
RSV rash
When your immune system fights a virus like RSV, you may develop a rash. But rashes are often caused by something else.
With an RSV rash, you may notice bumps, blotches, or spots on your skin. They may appear anywhere on your body and may spread to other areas.
A rash isn’t something you need to worry about with RSV. It’ll likely go away in a few days without treatment.
How long do RSV symptoms last?

You may develop RSV symptoms about 4-6 days after you’re infected. They can show up in different stages or all at one time. Mild symptoms of RSV may go away on their own in a week or two. But you may still have a cough for a few more weeks.
For children and teens, mild, cold-like symptoms usually go away in 7-21 days.
More severe cases of RSV may have longer lasting symptoms.

content_blocks.text: It’s also important to call your doctor if your child has a high risk of complications.

sections.heading: RSV in Babies
content: RSV is common, even in babies. Most children get it at least once by the time they’re 2 years old. Since RSV is very contagious, babies who are in child care or have siblings who are in child care or school are more likely to get RSV.
Symptoms of RSV in babies
RSV may look different in babies, especially if they’re young.
While babies may have mild cold-like symptoms from RSV, they have more risk of serious complications.
With a young baby, the first signs of RSV are:
Symptoms of severe RSV in babies include:
bullets: Severe trouble breathing, which may look like chest muscles and skin pulling inward as they breathe

sections.heading: Causes of RSV in babies
content: Your baby can get RSV if they come into contact with fluid from another infected person's mouth or nose. They may breathe in droplets from someone's sneeze or cough. Or, they may touch something that has fluids from an infected person and then touch their eyes, nose, or mouth.

content_blocks.text: Your baby can get RSV if they come into contact with fluid from another infected person's mouth or nose. They may breathe in droplets from someone's sneeze or cough. Or, they may touch something that has fluids from an infected person and then touch their eyes, nose, or mouth.

sections.heading: RSV in infants under 6 months
content: Infants have a higher risk of a severe or life-threatening infection. Premature infants and babies who are 6 months and younger have the highest risk.
If your baby is less than 6 months old and has signs of RSV, call your pediatrician .

content_blocks.text: Infants have a higher risk of a severe or life-threatening infection. Premature infants and babies who are 6 months and younger have the highest risk.
If your baby is less than 6 months old and has signs of RSV, call your pediatrician .

sections.heading: RSV in Adults
content: Adults often get RSV. The risk of problems is lower than it is for infants and older adults.
If you have certain health conditions, like heart disease or lung disease, you may have a higher risk of RSV leading to other health problems.
Symptoms of RSV in adults
For adults, RSV symptoms are similar to typical cold-like symptoms, such as a congested or runny nose, headache, or a sore throat. They may be mild and go away on their own.
RSV timeline in adults

After you've been exposed to RSV, your symptoms will usually show up after 4-6 days. These symptoms will usually last 2-8 days. It typically takes adults 1-2 weeks to fully recover unless you have more serious issues come up.

content_blocks.text: Adults often get RSV. The risk of problems is lower than it is for infants and older adults.
If you have certain health conditions, like heart disease or lung disease, you may have a higher risk of RSV leading to other health problems.
Symptoms of RSV in adults
For adults, RSV symptoms are similar to typical cold-like symptoms, such as a congested or runny nose, headache, or a sore throat. They may be mild and go away on their own.
RSV timeline in adults

After you've been exposed to RSV, your symptoms will usually show up after 4-6 days. These symptoms will usually last 2-8 days. It typically takes adults 1-2 weeks to fully recover unless you have more serious issues come up.

sections.heading: RSV in Children and Teens
content: RSV is common in children and teens but less likely to lead to problems.
Your child or teen may have a higher risk of complications if they have a weakened immune system from things like cancer or chemotherapy treatment .
The risk is also higher for children with neuromuscular disorders like muscular dystrophy and conditions like congenital heart disease and chronic lung disease.
Symptoms of RSV in children and teens
Older children often have mild, cold-like symptoms from RSV like the ones listed above. They may have other symptoms like an ear infection, eye redness, eye irritation, or eye discharge.
If your child or teen has severe RSV, common symptoms may include a cough and a sore, scratchy throat.

sections.heading: RSV in Older Adults
content: If you’re an older adult, RSV can be more dangerous. If you’re 75 or older, your doctor may recommend a single dose of the RSV vaccine to prevent problems . Experts also recommend a single dose of the vaccine for adults 60 to 74 years old and up who are at high risk for severe RSV disease.
Symptoms of RSV in older adults
In addition to the typical symptoms of RSV, older adults are at risk for more severe issues including pneumonia or worsened symptoms of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease ( COPD ).

content_blocks.text: If you’re an older adult, RSV can be more dangerous. If you’re 75 or older, your doctor may recommend a single dose of the RSV vaccine to prevent problems . Experts also recommend a single dose of the vaccine for adults 60 to 74 years old and up who are at high risk for severe RSV disease.
Symptoms of RSV in older adults
In addition to the typical symptoms of RSV, older adults are at risk for more severe issues including pneumonia or worsened symptoms of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease ( COPD ).

sections.heading: RSV Transmission
content: RSV travels on small droplets through the air. It enters your body through your eyes, nose, or mouth.
RSV may live for hours on hard surfaces like countertops and toys. It has a shorter lifespan on soft surfaces like tissues.
Is RSV contagious?
Yes. RSV is contagious and spreads easily. Adults may get it when:
bullets: You touch a doorknob or other contaminated surface, then touch your face

content_blocks.text: RSV travels on small droplets through the air. It enters your body through your eyes, nose, or mouth.
RSV may live for hours on hard surfaces like countertops and toys. It has a shorter lifespan on soft surfaces like tissues.
Is RSV contagious?
Yes. RSV is contagious and spreads easily. Adults may get it when:
associated_bullets: You touch a doorknob or other contaminated surface, then touch your face

content: Babies may get it when:
How long is RSV contagious?
When you get RSV, you may be contagious for about 3-8 days. You’re most contagious during the first week, but you may be contagious 1-2 days before you notice any symptoms.
Babies and people with weak immune systems may be contagious longer, up to 4 weeks after symptoms go away.
RSV incubation period
The incubation period, or the time it takes to notice symptoms after being exposed to the virus, can be anywhere from 1 to 10 days.
bullets: They touch a contaminated surface (like a toy) and then put their fingers in their mouth or on other parts of their face
Another child coughs or sneezes near them (especially because children often don't cover their mouths)

content_blocks.text: Babies may get it when:
associated_bullets: They touch a contaminated surface (like a toy) and then put their fingers in their mouth or on other parts of their face
Another child coughs or sneezes near them (especially because children often don't cover their mouths)

Babies and people with weak immune systems may be contagious longer, up to 4 weeks after symptoms go away.
RSV incubation period
The incubation period, or the time it takes to notice symptoms after being exposed to the virus, can be anywhere from 1 to 10 days.

sections.heading: RSV Diagnosis
content: To find out if you have RSV, your doctor will ask about your symptoms and medical history. They may listen to your lungs, check your blood oxygen level, and do a swab test on your mucus.

sections.heading: RSV Diagnosis
content: To find out if you have RSV, your doctor will ask about your symptoms and medical history. They may listen to your lungs, check your blood oxygen level, and do a swab test on your mucus.

content_blocks.text: To find out if you have RSV, your doctor will ask about your symptoms and medical history. They may listen to your lungs, check your blood oxygen level, and do a swab test on your mucus.

content: Your doctor may look for signs of complications by doing tests like a chest X-ray.
RSV test
Your doctor probably won’t do a test for RSV unless you or your child has high risk factors or signs of severe RSV.
If so, they may take a sample of nose fluids by using a cotton swab or bulb syringe. They’ll test it for RSV.
There are two common tests for RSV:
Real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR). This test can be used in infants, older children, and adults.
Antigen testing. This test is best suited for children and not as sensitive to find RSV in adults.
Less common RSV tests include:
You can also buy an at-home RSV test. With this test, you'll swab the inside of your nostril and send it into a lab for testing. You can get this test without a prescription.
bullets: Serology (this test is usually only used during studies)

content_blocks.text: Your doctor may look for signs of complications by doing tests like a chest X-ray.
RSV test
Your doctor probably won’t do a test for RSV unless you or your child has high risk factors or signs of severe RSV.
If so, they may take a sample of nose fluids by using a cotton swab or bulb syringe. They’ll test it for RSV.

associated_bullets: Serology (this test is usually only used during studies)

content_blocks.text: You can also buy an at-home RSV test. With this test, you'll swab the inside of your nostril and send it into a lab for testing. You can get this test without a prescription.

sections.heading: How to Know If It’s RSV, Cold, Flu, or COVID
content: RSV vs cold

content_blocks.text: RSV vs cold

content: RSV symptoms are similar to the common cold. You'll most likely start to notice cold symptoms 1 to 3 days after being exposed to the virus. There are a few things that separate RSV from a cold:
Your doctor probably won’t try to figure out whether you or your child has a cold or RSV unless you have a high risk or signs of severe RSV.
RSV vs flu

Symptoms of RSV and the flu may be similar, but RSV usually stays in your upper respiratory tract. If you or your child has diarrhea, nausea, or vomiting, it’s a sign of something else, like flu or COVID-19.
Another sign that it’s the flu instead of RSV is if the sickness starts with a high fever. RSV usually starts with cold-like symptoms.
While they're possible with RSV, you're  more likely to have body aches and fatigue with the flu.
bullets: If you're wheezing, it's more likely that you have RSV, as this symptom isn't as common with a mild cold.
While a cold and RSV both last for a week or two, RSV symptoms tend to get worse over time unlike a cold.

content_blocks.text: RSV symptoms are similar to the common cold. You'll most likely start to notice cold symptoms 1 to 3 days after being exposed to the virus. There are a few things that separate RSV from a cold:
associated_bullets: If you're wheezing, it's more likely that you have RSV, as this symptom isn't as common with a mild cold.
While a cold and RSV both last for a week or two, RSV symptoms tend to get worse over time unlike a cold.

content_blocks.text: Your doctor probably won’t try to figure out whether you or your child has a cold or RSV unless you have a high risk or signs of severe RSV.
RSV vs flu

Symptoms of RSV and the flu may be similar, but RSV usually stays in your upper respiratory tract. If you or your child has diarrhea, nausea, or vomiting, it’s a sign of something else, like flu or COVID-19.
Another sign that it’s the flu instead of RSV is if the sickness starts with a high fever. RSV usually starts with cold-like symptoms.
While they're possible with RSV, you're  more likely to have body aches and fatigue with the flu.

content: Your doctor may look for signs of complications by doing tests like a chest X-ray.
RSV test
Your doctor probably won’t do a test for RSV unless you or your child has high risk factors or signs of severe RSV.
If so, they may take a sample of nose fluids by using a cotton swab or bulb syringe. They’ll test it for RSV.
There are two common tests for RSV:
Real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR). This test can be used in infants, older children, and adults.
Antigen testing. This test is best suited for children and not as sensitive to find RSV in adults.
Less common RSV tests include:
You can also buy an at-home RSV test. With this test, you'll swab the inside of your nostril and send it into a lab for testing. You can get this test without a prescription.
bullets: Serology (this test is usually only used during studies)

sections.heading: How to Know If It’s RSV, Cold, Flu, or COVID
content: RSV vs cold

content_blocks.text: RSV vs cold

content: RSV symptoms are similar to the common cold. You'll most likely start to notice cold symptoms 1 to 3 days after being exposed to the virus. There are a few things that separate RSV from a cold:
Your doctor probably won’t try to figure out whether you or your child has a cold or RSV unless you have a high risk or signs of severe RSV.
RSV vs flu

Symptoms of RSV and the flu may be similar, but RSV usually stays in your upper respiratory tract. If you or your child has diarrhea, nausea, or vomiting, it’s a sign of something else, like flu or COVID-19.
Another sign that it’s the flu instead of RSV is if the sickness starts with a high fever. RSV usually starts with cold-like symptoms.
While they're possible with RSV, you're  more likely to have body aches and fatigue with the flu.
bullets: If you're wheezing, it's more likely that you have RSV, as this symptom isn't as common with a mild cold.
While a cold and RSV both last for a week or two, RSV symptoms tend to get worse over time unlike a cold.

content_blocks.text: RSV symptoms are similar to the common cold. You'll most likely start to notice cold symptoms 1 to 3 days after being exposed to the virus. There are a few things that separate RSV from a cold:
associated_bullets: If you're wheezing, it's more likely that you have RSV, as this symptom isn't as common with a mild cold.
While a cold and RSV both last for a week or two, RSV symptoms tend to get worse over time unlike a cold.

content_blocks.text: Your doctor probably won’t try to figure out whether you or your child has a cold or RSV unless you have a high risk or signs of severe RSV.
RSV vs flu

Symptoms of RSV and the flu may be similar, but RSV usually stays in your upper respiratory tract. If you or your child has diarrhea, nausea, or vomiting, it’s a sign of something else, like flu or COVID-19.
Another sign that it’s the flu instead of RSV is if the sickness starts with a high fever. RSV usually starts with cold-like symptoms.
While they're possible with RSV, you're  more likely to have body aches and fatigue with the flu.

content: Flu symptoms tend to pop up 1 to 4 days after you're exposed to the virus. They'll last around 5 to 7 days. But if you've had the flu vaccine, they may last for a shorter amount of time and be less severe.
RSV vs COVID

The symptoms of RSV and COVID can be alike. But RSV usually only affects your upper respiratory tract. It's still possible with RSV, but COVID is more likely to cause difficulty breathing, fatigue, and a sore throat. RSV is more likely to cause wheezing, while that's less common with COVID.
If you or your child has gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea, nausea, or vomiting, it may be COVID.
Your COVID symptoms may appear 2 to 14 days after you come into contact with virus. They usually last one to two weeks. But severe cases can have symptoms that last up to months.

content_blocks.text: Flu symptoms tend to pop up 1 to 4 days after you're exposed to the virus. They'll last around 5 to 7 days. But if you've had the flu vaccine, they may last for a shorter amount of time and be less severe.
RSV vs COVID

The symptoms of RSV and COVID can be alike. But RSV usually only affects your upper respiratory tract. It's still possible with RSV, but COVID is more likely to cause difficulty breathing, fatigue, and a sore throat. RSV is more likely to cause wheezing, while that's less common with COVID.
If you or your child has gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea, nausea, or vomiting, it may be COVID.
Your COVID symptoms may appear 2 to 14 days after you come into contact with virus. They usually last one to two weeks. But severe cases can have symptoms that last up to months.

sections.heading: RSV Vaccine
content: Some cases of RSV can be prevented through a vaccine . There are two vaccines: Abrysvo and Arexvy.

content_blocks.text: Some cases of RSV can be prevented through a vaccine . There are two vaccines: Abrysvo and Arexvy.

content: Doctors may recommend an RSV vaccine for adults who are:

Experts found that RSV vaccines help lower the risk of disease in people 60 years old and up by 80-90% in the first season after a vaccine. Arexvy was 77-83% effective in stopping RSV-related hospitalization in people 60 and up. Abrysvo was 73-79% successful in doing the same.
Adults can get the RSV vaccine at any time. But it's best to get it in the late summer and early fall before RSV begins to spread around.
The protection you get from a vaccine goes down over time, but it still offers protection against severe RSV illness for at least 2 years.

While there's no RSV vaccine for babies, your infant or young child can get immunized with RSV monoclonal antibodies. Your baby can get this even if you've already had the RSV vaccination while pregnant with them.
bullets: 32-26 weeks pregnant, to protect your baby after they’re born

content_blocks.text: Doctors may recommend an RSV vaccine for adults who are:
associated_bullets: 32-26 weeks pregnant, to protect your baby after they’re born

content_blocks.text: Experts found that RSV vaccines help lower the risk of disease in people 60 years old and up by 80-90% in the first season after a vaccine. Arexvy was 77-83% effective in stopping RSV-related hospitalization in people 60 and up. Abrysvo was 73-79% successful in doing the same.
Adults can get the RSV vaccine at any time. But it's best to get it in the late summer and early fall before RSV begins to spread around.
The protection you get from a vaccine goes down over time, but it still offers protection against severe RSV illness for at least 2 years.

While there's no RSV vaccine for babies, your infant or young child can get immunized with RSV monoclonal antibodies. Your baby can get this even if you've already had the RSV vaccination while pregnant with them.

content: Experts recommend one dose of nirsevimab for infants under 8 months who were born right before or are going into their first RSV season. They also recommend a single dose of nirsevimab for infants and children 8-19 months who are entering their second RSV season and have a higher risk of severe RSV disease.

Another RSV preventative antibody called palivizumab is available for children 24 months and younger who have a condition that puts them at high risk for severe RSV disease. Your baby's doctor will give it to them once a month during RSV season. They should get their first dose before the season starts.

sections.heading: RSV Prevention
content: There’s a lot you can do to stop the spread of RSV, including:
bullets: Cover your mouth when you cough and sneeze
Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer
Clean objects and surfaces like doorknobs, countertops, handles, and toys often
Open windows, use an air purifier, or spend time outdoors
Don’t share drinking glasses with others
Don’t smoke. Babies who breathe in tobacco smoke have a higher risk of RSV and complications

content_blocks.text: There’s a lot you can do to stop the spread of RSV, including:
associated_bullets: Cover your mouth when you cough and sneeze
Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer
Clean objects and surfaces like doorknobs, countertops, handles, and toys often
Open windows, use an air purifier, or spend time outdoors
Don’t share drinking glasses with others
Don’t smoke. Babies who breathe in tobacco smoke have a higher risk of RSV and complications

sections.heading: RSV precautions
content: If you or your baby is sick with RSV, you can wear a mask to help lower the chances that you spread the virus.
While you don't need to quarantine with RSV, it's smart to stay home from school or work until you feel better. This will also help you avoid spreading the virus to other people.

content_blocks.text: If you or your baby is sick with RSV, you can wear a mask to help lower the chances that you spread the virus.
While you don't need to quarantine with RSV, it's smart to stay home from school or work until you feel better. This will also help you avoid spreading the virus to other people.

sections.heading: RSV Treatment
content: RSV treatment in babies
If your child has trouble breathing, your doctor may recommend an RSV nebulizer with albuterol to help them breathe better.
If your baby or toddler has RSV, they may need to go to the hospital so doctors can watch them closely and give them treatment for breathing problems or dehydration.
RSV treatment in adults
When you have RSV with mild, cold-like symptoms, it usually goes away on its own.

In most cases, you don’t need a special treatment like RSV medication. You can use over-the-counter medication like ibuprofen or acetaminophen to treat a fever. Staying hydrated helps, so try to drink plenty of water.

content_blocks.text: RSV treatment in babies
If your child has trouble breathing, your doctor may recommend an RSV nebulizer with albuterol to help them breathe better.
If your baby or toddler has RSV, they may need to go to the hospital so doctors can watch them closely and give them treatment for breathing problems or dehydration.
RSV treatment in adults

In most cases, you don’t need a special treatment like RSV medication. You can use over-the-counter medication like ibuprofen or acetaminophen to treat a fever. Staying hydrated helps, so try to drink plenty of water.

sections.heading: Treatment for severe RSV
content: Only 2% of people with RSV need to go to the hospital for a more serious treatment.
If you go to the hospital, you may get:
Antibiotics for RSV
RSV is a virus, so antibiotics don’t help. Antibiotics fight bacteria, not viruses.
bullets: Oxygen through a mask, nasal prongs, or a ventilator

content_blocks.text: Only 2% of people with RSV need to go to the hospital for a more serious treatment.
If you go to the hospital, you may get:
associated_bullets: Oxygen through a mask, nasal prongs, or a ventilator

content_blocks.text: Antibiotics for RSV
RSV is a virus, so antibiotics don’t help. Antibiotics fight bacteria, not viruses.

sections.heading: RSV Home Remedies
content: There’s a lot you can do to feel more comfortable when you have RSV.
bullets: Use a cool-mist vaporizer to help with breathing and coughing
Try saline nose drops for a stuffy nose
Use a baby aspirator to clear your baby’s stuffy nose
Try an over-the-counter medication like acetaminophen or ibuprofen

items: Use a cool-mist vaporizer to help with breathing and coughing
Try saline nose drops for a stuffy nose
Use a baby aspirator to clear your baby’s stuffy nose
Try an over-the-counter medication like acetaminophen or ibuprofen
Drink a lot of fluids

items: Use a cool-mist vaporizer to help with breathing and coughing
Try saline nose drops for a stuffy nose
Use a baby aspirator to clear your baby’s stuffy nose
Try an over-the-counter medication like acetaminophen or ibuprofen
Drink a lot of fluids

content: Watch out for things that may be harmful with RSV. Consider these safety tips:
If your baby has RSV, they may not want to drink anything. Try to offer fluids often, in small amounts.
bullets: Always clean a cool-mist humidifier so it doesn’t grow mold and bacteria
Don’t use a hot-water or steam humidifier
Don’t give your child aspirin, which is linked to a life-threatening condition called Reye syndrome
Don’t give your child over-the-counter cold medicines, which may be harmful to young children

content_blocks.text: Watch out for things that may be harmful with RSV. Consider these safety tips:
associated_bullets: Always clean a cool-mist humidifier so it doesn’t grow mold and bacteria
Don’t use a hot-water or steam humidifier
Don’t give your child aspirin, which is linked to a life-threatening condition called Reye syndrome
Don’t give your child over-the-counter cold medicines, which may be harmful to young children

content_blocks.text: If your baby has RSV, they may not want to drink anything. Try to offer fluids often, in small amounts.

sections.heading: RSV Complications
content: RSV may lead to complications, especially in young babies, older adults, and people with other high-risk conditions.
RSV complications may include:
Pneumonia. This infection causes inflammation in the air sacs in one or both of your lungs. It can lead to cough with phlegm, fever, difficulty breathing, and chills.
Bronchiolitis. This is a common lung infection that affects children and babies. It leads to swelling, irritation, and mucus in the airways of your lungs.

Middle ear infection. This infection affects the air-filled space behind your eardrum. Tubes that run from your ear to the back of your throat become blocked and swollen. This causes mucus to build-up in the middle of your ear.
Asthma. This condition causes your airways to become inflamed and narrowed at certain moments. It can make it harder for air to move out of your airways when you breathe.
Repeated infections. You may have RSV multiple times, even within the same RSV season.
Bronchitis. This is when the airways that lead to your lungs become inflamed and fill up with mucus. It can cause a constant cough that may last 2 or more weeks.
In some cases, you or your child may need to go to the hospital for severe cases on RSV.

RSV complications may include:

Middle ear infection. This infection affects the air-filled space behind your eardrum. Tubes that run from your ear to the back of your throat become blocked and swollen. This causes mucus to build-up in the middle of your ear.
Asthma. This condition causes your airways to become inflamed and narrowed at certain moments. It can make it harder for air to move out of your airways when you breathe.
Repeated infections. You may have RSV multiple times, even within the same RSV season.
Bronchitis. This is when the airways that lead to your lungs become inflamed and fill up with mucus. It can cause a constant cough that may last 2 or more weeks.
In some cases, you or your child may need to go to the hospital for severe cases on RSV.

sections.heading: RSV Takeaways
bullets: RSV is a common, contagious virus that typically has mild, cold-like symptoms
RSV usually goes away on its own, in about a week or two
It’s usually just a matter of time before you feel better. But RSV may get serious quickly, especially in young babies, older adults, and people with high-risk conditions or a weakened immune system
It’s important to watch for symptoms of severe RSV, especially in babies

sections.heading: RSV FAQs
content: Why is RSV so serious?

RSV may get serious quickly. If it spreads, it may lead to pneumonia or bronchiolitis. When RSV leads to lung inflammation, it may be very serious, especially for young infants and toddlers, older adults, and people who are immunocompromised or have chronic heart or lung disease.
Can adults get RSV from kids?
Yes. RSV is very contagious, and kids may bring it home from school or child care. You can also get RSV if your baby has it and you kiss their face.

content_blocks.text: Why is RSV so serious?

RSV may get serious quickly. If it spreads, it may lead to pneumonia or bronchiolitis. When RSV leads to lung inflammation, it may be very serious, especially for young infants and toddlers, older adults, and people who are immunocompromised or have chronic heart or lung disease.
Can adults get RSV from kids?
Yes. RSV is very contagious, and kids may bring it home from school or child care. You can also get RSV if your baby has it and you kiss their face.

sections.heading: What are the stages of RSV?
content: You may notice RSV symptoms about 2-5 days after you’ve been exposed to it. The first stage is mild and feels like a cold. Then it may move into the lungs and lead to coughing or wheezing. Then it may lead to respiratory disease, which you need to be hospitalized for.
What is the fastest way to get rid of RSV?
There’s no specific treatment to get rid of RSV quickly. It usually takes 1-2 weeks to go away. Staying hydrated may help.
What is the best medicine for RSV?
You can use over-the-counter pain relievers and fever reducers to help with pain and fever. But there’s no specific RSV medication.
Does RSV go away on its own?
Yes, RSV usually goes away on its own. But if there are complications, you or your child may need to go to the hospital for special treatment.
What is a good remedy for RSV?

content_blocks.text: You may notice RSV symptoms about 2-5 days after you’ve been exposed to it. The first stage is mild and feels like a cold. Then it may move into the lungs and lead to coughing or wheezing. Then it may lead to respiratory disease, which you need to be hospitalized for.
What is the fastest way to get rid of RSV?
There’s no specific treatment to get rid of RSV quickly. It usually takes 1-2 weeks to go away. Staying hydrated may help.
What is the best medicine for RSV?
You can use over-the-counter pain relievers and fever reducers to help with pain and fever. But there’s no specific RSV medication.
Does RSV go away on its own?
Yes, RSV usually goes away on its own. But if there are complications, you or your child may need to go to the hospital for special treatment.
What is a good remedy for RSV?

content: Try at-home remedies like drinking fluids, using saline nasal drops, and using a cool-mist vaporizer.
How to cure RSV?
While some cases may go away with time, you may need over-the-counter medications or other treatments to help you feel better. Rest and self care are also important to cure a case of RSV.

meta_description: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV): What to know, including symptoms, how to know when it’s serious, who has a high risk, treatment, prevention, and more.
